bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, September 28, 1928

div1.p: Frost sends information Carter can use to verify references for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, September 28, 1928
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
September 28, 1928.
Miss Laura A. Carter,
The Westmoreland Apts.,
2122 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.
My dear Miss Laura:
div1.p:
I have made fair progress this week on editing
the yellow fever manuscript and have practically fin-
ished Section I, although there are still a number of minor
points to be cleared up, especially as to unlocated or
unverified references. Early next week, I will under-
take to list the references on which I am still doubtful
and which are not available to me here, and will ask
you to let me have a report on any of them that you may
be able to locate in Washington. In the meantime, I
have just one or two items to note.

(1) Regarding the unidentified(?) reference to
Peryassú, (1908) on page 12 of your copy of manuscript,
this almost necessarily must refer to his publication
“Os culicideos do Brazil”, Inst. de Manguinhos, Rio de
Janeiro. I am not quite certain from the card which
is enclosed whether or not this reference in the original
has been verified. I take it, however, that you have
verified it in the original. If so, please merely return
it to me without doing anything further.
ok

(2) The reference to Goeldi, page 8, re. occurrence
of aegypti larvae in street gutters, is possibly an error.
Howard, Dyar and Knab on page 284 quote Durham as having
observed the larvae in rain gutters at Para. Possibly
“Goeldi” in your father's MS should have been “Durham”. In any case, this
quotation may well be substituted for the unlocated re-
ference to Goeldi.

(3) The Warren mentioned in regard to the Boston
epidemic of 1798 is probably H. Warren. I find in
I. p. 36/7 La Roche the following reference: Warren, H., Fever of
Boston in 1798; in Tytler, J., A treatise on the plague
ok
-2-
and yellow fever, 8 vo. Salem, Massachusetts, 1799. p. 499 et seq. If
you can find Tytler's book you can probably locate Warren's
ok article therein.
ok See XX

(4) Regarding the quotations from Nopptt, I should
like you to look up his second (1857) paper again. I ok
suspect that your Father's reference (page 23) to the
epidemic of 1843 is a typographical error; that it should
refer to the epidemic of 1853. It seems to be a fact
that Nopptt was somewhat impressed with the evidence of
contagiousness in this later epidemic. Would it be
possible to have the book containing this article sent
to me?
Send Carter's MSS
&
Nott's articles

I had a very pleasant visit a few days ago from
Colonel Russell, who seemed to be much pleased with the
progress that has been made and to be generally in very
good humor. He was quite agreeable to my suggestion that
I have the edited MS retyped in duplicate or triplicate
before sending it on to you. him.

By the end of next week, I may want to ask you
to come over here again, but it does not seem necessary
just yet, as I am having very little difficulty making
out your notes.
div1.closer:
With best regards,
Sincerely yours, W. H. F. whf/f
ok

from Dr. Warren, which he obligingly sent to two
physicians in Salem, gives an accurate account of the
distemper which prevailed in Boston last
